New YouTube video. This is the next video in the free gardening course series. 

In this new video, I go over a simple bed turnover which is when you move from one crop to the next. In the garden you can keep it simple using a rake instead of something like the Iconoclast and simple fertilizer addition. 

Previously I discussed creating great vegetable starts using Winstrip, soil block or regular 1020 trays. I also discussed watering and germination. Check out the whole series by following the link in profile.

I love winter growing. It is amazing walking through snow and opening the hoop house door to see a living wonderland of vegetable bounty. I think winter greens are the most superior in flavor. I have been growing through our harsh upstate NY winters (zone 5a) since our first year farming many many years ago and it never gets old. 

We use a combination of table grown shoots and micro greens, unheated hardy greens and heated in ground sensitive greens and storage crops. Some of the storage crops like carrots and onions stay stored in the soil in the bed. Some are in the cold room. 

#wintergrowing #wintercrops #hoophouse #greenhouse #zone5a #marketfarm #marketfarming #notill #notillfarm #organicfarm #wintergreens #neversinkfarm #smallfarm #marketfarm #marketfarmcourse #familyfarm #farmlife #growingvegetables #growyourown #microfarm #humanscaleagricture #smallscalefarm

Aerial view of the farm. 

We are deep into planning for the new season. 

In the field, we have been continually straightening rows for the past decade. When we started, we oriented rows along an old fence line and that caused all the rows to be aligned very strangely.  Over the years, we slowly moved them. I feel that last year we finally got all the rows to equal length and the field relatively square. It was a lot work but it makes planning so much easier for me. I plan in blocks of 8 rows or approximately 3,000 sf so if the blocks are not equal then my cheat sheets for starts don’t work very well. 

We have also been removing older hoop houses from the field and concentrating our hoop house investment into the larger permanent houses. 

If you are a home gardener or wanting to start, please check out my new free gardening course up on my YouTube channel. 

#neversinkfarm #notill #notillfarming #conorcrickmore #smallfarm #marketfarm #marketfarming #neversinkfarmcourse #marketfarmcourse #familyfarm #farmlife #growingvegetables #growyourown #microfarm#humanscaleagricture #smallscalefarm #growingcucumbers  #cucumbers #hookandwicket #qlipr

I hope everyone is able to take time to celebrate with family and friends today. At Neversink, we are opening a great bottle of natural champagne and reminiscing about this last year and all the time we were so lucky to spend together. We are looking forward to hopefully another year of being on this planet trying to make the best of it while improving the world in our own small way. 

Cheers to all and a special toast to the farmers and Gardeners! And if you are dreaming about becoming a farmer, I hope you make it happen this year. No better time than right now!

#happynewyear #neversinkfarm #notill #notillfarming #conorcrickmore #smallfarm #marketfarm #marketfarming #neversinkfarmcourse #marketfarmcourse #familyfarm #farmlife#growingvegetables #growyourown #microfarm#humanscaleagricture #smallscalefarm

The first plan I make in the spring is where everything is going into the hoop houses. It is a general plan so I get an idea of where to start direct seeding and when to start transplants in the propagation house. For Tomatoes and Peppers, the plan more importantly lets me know how much of each variety I need to begin with. For most things, I start a certain amount on a schedule. I just need to know when to start that up. I have cheat sheets for most of that, which remain relatively unchanged year after year.

Overall, I keep it simple.

Course Members - I just uploaded the “Hoop House Layout for Spring 2023” into the course. Check it out in the resources under crop planning and throw any questions you have for me into the forum.

#neversinkfarm #notill #notillfarming #conorcrickmore #smallfarm #marketfarm #marketfarming #neversinkfarmcourse #marketfarmcourse #familyfarm #farmlife #growingvegetables #growyourown #microfarm #humanscaleagricture #smallscalefarm #growingtomatoes #heirloomtomatoes #tomatoes

Winter lettuce house. 

It is sometimes hard to clear out houses when things look good. Other times, when things have gone to crap, it is liberating. 

Either way, the seasons change and we have to move on. Our tomato house has to get prepared early for planting. I like to get the soil loaded with compost, any balancing amendments, water well with wobblers and the let everything soak together for a few weeks. I feel this wakes the soil up after a winters slumber as well it gives it a good feeding. 

Course members - I just uploaded a seeding schedule for the spring hoop houses. Check resources - “Seeding Schedule 2023 Hoop House.

#winterfarming #livingsoil #soilprep #bedprep #compost #smallscalefarm #notill #notillfarming #hoophouse #farmlife #neversinkfarm #lettuce #yearroundgrowing #turnover #smallfarm #regenerativemarketgardening #marketfarm #lettucerows

So excited to announce that the FREE “Introduction to Profitable Market Farming Course” is open once again.

This free introductory course is about encouraging and inspiring new and beginning farmers. I believe our communities are better off with more small-scale farmers and with more people taking control of their financial independence by owning their own business. I hope this course will in some way will help to achieve that goal. Signup now and start on your journey to finding land and start your dream of becoming a farmer. To register for this free introductory course, follow the link in my profile. Course is available until 1/24/2023

🍅Starting a Farm 🥬👩‍🌾👨‍🌾🥬
The first module of nine lessons is about my journey from the city to the country and becoming a farm business owner. Based on that experience, I discuss in these lessons the crucial qualities that make good farm land. Also in this module, I go into further detail about laying out your farm and the smart investments one should make once you find your property. Enjoy. 
#neversinkfarmcourse #introtomarketfarming #marketfarmcourse #morefarms #smallfarm #beginningfarmerproject #marketfarm #marketfarming

The Living Soil Module is part of The FREE Intro to Market Farming which will close on 1/24/2023. It is long, over 35 lessons, so make sure to give yourself enough time to watch it all. 

🌻🌻Living Soil👩‍🌾👨‍🌾

The second module made of Five Lessons covers one of your farms most important resources. As you may know, I am a no till farm, so I never drag a BCS or Tractor out into the field and turn the soil. Whether you till or do not this module will be helpful. It covers the importance of compost and managing living soil. It also goes into balancing soil nutrients and the daily task of turning over beds. I believe 90% of a farms issue with poor growth, disease, or pests can be solved with great soil management. Enjoy!

This free introductory course is about encouraging and inspiring new and beginning farmers. I believe our communities are better off with more small-scale farmers and with more people taking control of their financial independence by owning their own business. I hope this course will in some way will help to achieve that goal. Signup now and start on your journey to finding land and start your dream of becoming a farmer. To register for this free introductory course, follow the link in my profile.

#neversinkfarmcourse #introtomarketfarming #marketfarmcourse #morefarms #smallfarm #beginningfarmerproject #marketfarm #marketfarming #livingsoil #compost #bedturnover #beginningfarmers #beginningfarmerproject #notill

The FREE Intro to Market Farming Course’s third module is all about starting your crops.

👨‍🌾👩‍🌾Starting the Veg🌱🌱🌱

It is made of Seven Lessons covering introductions to paperpots, propagation house, direct seeding, transplanting, cuttings, grafting and plug trays. It is a big and important subject. It is where the creation of your wonderful vegetable products begin. Starting crops needs to be done efficiently, on time, and well or it will be very difficult to start over. You need product to sell, right? Enjoy!

We grow radish all winter but when temps fall it must be in the wash house which is heated to just above freezing.  A necessity here in upstate NY, zone 5a. 
🍒🍒🍒🍒
It adds fantastic color to the winter market table, which is needed among all the greens. It certainly helps to bring the in the customers. 

Radish do not grow much during the winter. We are seeding now for early spring harvest. Usually radish take just a few weeks to mature but at this time of year it takes months. Totally worth the real estate. Once spring arrives though, all radishes move to the field. 

Farm Course Members - check out the new indoor seeding schedule I am using this year on the resources page. 
#wintergrowing #hoophouse #ondoorgrowing #yearroundfarm #neversinkfarm #winterveg #notill #radish #winterfarkersmarket #familyfarm #organicfarm #organicfarming

Seeds from @highmowingorganicseeds

I just received an awesome message from a new/aspiring farmer....

“Dear Conor, ... I just wanted to say that I just enrolled in your free course and quite literally was about to burst into tears when I saw the wealth of information you are sharing with the world - what an incredibly generous gift to all of us aspiring to grow small scale but just need a little support and encouragement to jump into the farming adventure. With deep, deep gratitude,”

Knowing that I am helping beginning farmers is what helps keep me motivated. Without feedback, it would be hard to keep me inspired to make more free content. Thank you so much!

The third module in The Free Intro to Market Farming Course is all about ...

Weeds!

Like every subject in farming,  it is big and important. So, for the intro course, I go over some of the most important tools and techniques that use to keep weeds at bay at Neversink Farm.

Neversink Farm started from very humble beginnings. We had a few beds, a small greenhouse and a love of growing things. 
We grew it quickly so that we could earn a living, have kids, but that happened purely through selling vegetables. We have kept Neversink Farms size pretty much the same for many years once we reached a comfortable working acreage for us, 1.3 acres, with an infrastructure that made working that land easy.
But what is important is that we started very small and if you have a desire to farm, you can start small too. 
Right now, my Free Introduction to Market Farming Course is open. It is about encouraging and inspiring new and beginning farmers. I believe our communities are better off with more small-scale farmers and with more people taking control of their financial independence by owning their own business. I hope this course will in some way will help to achieve that goal. Signup now and start on your journey to finding land and start your dream of becoming a farmer. To register for this free introductory course, follow the link in my profile. Course is available until 1/24/2023

Just a few days left to Join my Free Introduction to Profitable Market Farming Course.

The next module is 
🌱🌱Harvesting and Processing Vegatbles 🥕🥕🥕

You have managed great living soil, planted and cultivated (first three modules) and now Hopefully you will spend most of the season harvesting and processing vegetables. Efficiency in this area means getting much more done every day. The more veggies at market the better. They also must look great and the wash station is where the magic happens. It is such an important part of your infrastructure. Please join me and take a look at my wash and pack area as I explain some of the systems, I use at Neversink Farm to get vegetables out of the field and to market quickly.

The next module in The Free Introduction to Profitable Market Farming Course is

🥒🥒🥦🥦Marketing🍅🍅🥕🥕

Marketing your products is when all the hard work pays off. Entrepreneurs, farmers included, must be great marketers. If you are passionate about what you do and the vegetables that you create then you are already ahead of the game.  You can funnel that passion into getting your product in front of potential customers. I have sold at thousands of farmers markets over the years and have continued to refine our marketing practices. You can see the famous Neversink Farm Rootwall and Market display duplicated everywhere. I really enjoy marketing my vegetables and as a result, I have gained a lot of insight into what works and what doesn't. #neversinkrootwall #neversinkmarketsetup

Keeping the beds planted through winter means early veg come spring. 

Pic above taken yesterday inside Hoop House 5 at Neversink; the only heated house this winter. It is our wash station as well so we have a large variety of crops here. You can see kale to the right. We also have celery, parsley and arugula. 

Unheated houses have swaths of spinach, carrots, onions, leeks, tatsoi etc. 

Salanova, 72 cell tray, 4x4 grid, 30” wide beds, heavily composted in Fall, water once a month in winter overhead on sunny day, harvest three or four times before flipping. 

#winterfarm #growyearround #hoophouse #winstrip #winstriptrays #airprunetrays #lettuceplanting #thegridder #neversinkfarm #organicfarm #bedturnover #notill

My Intro course just ended this morning and Wow! We had over 3,000 beginning farmers joining. It is just amazing. Small scale farming definitely continues to be on the rise and I am stoked!

I also got another note that I wanted to share. Thank you! I really appreciate it so much. Getting notes like this makes the work worth it and helps me do more of it. 
“I just finished the Into to Market Gardening course and loved it, want more! ... The modules and intro are legit some of the best resources I’ve ever come across and I’ve taken multiple intros to permaculture classes and even Master Gardener classes, so kudos to Conor and the entire team as this is maybe the most impactful thing a lot of aspiring farmers/homesteaders will ever come across. “

Don’t worry. If you missed it, we will offer it again this year. We are also talking about adding to it this summer, which should be a great time.

We are in the midst of starting seedlings as I imagine all of you are. It something the family loves doing together. Times in the prop house filling trays are some of the best times farming.

#neversinkfarmcourse #neversinkfarm #neversinktools #farmingfamily #notill #farmfromabove #familyfarm #organicfarm # notillfarming #marketfarmcourse

Say Hi to Wini, the newest member of the Neversink Farm team! Wini was a stray that came to us through our awesome local animal rescue. 

She is still learning where the paths are and not to trample the lettuce but she is getting there. I think the rabbits are in trouble 😉

For those interested - The Neversink Farm Course registration ends soon so head on over using the link in profile. 

#farmdog #miniwini #miniwinitray #farmlife #farmkids #organicfarm

The Seed to Plate video series is a project that we did during the lockdown to not only keep ourselves busy and to have a good time but also to keep our minds occupied on something creative. It definitely achieved that goal for us but after filming we moved onto to other things and did not get back to finishing the edit, until now. I am excited to finally release it. I hope you enjoy the show as much as we did while making it. 

Each episode follows one crop in the garden from seeding, to growing, to harvest, and then to plate. In the end, I cook a meal with that vegetable at the barn with my family. Along the way, we have a blast farming, gardening, and working on projects around the farm. 
There are eight episodes and the first will be released on our YouTube Channel “NeversinkFarm” this Sunday night, March 12th,  at 7pm.  New episodes will be released for eights week, same day and time. 
If you have the ability to watch on a large screen, we recommend it. It is all shot in 4k.

The great Mark Dissin, volunteered time to help us with production and really raised the bar for us on this project. Thanks Mark. @presliced_productions 
My buddy Gregory, @gregoryalanisakov was cool enough to license his music. 

#SeedtoPlateNevesink #SeedtoPlate #NeversinkFarm #FoodFamilyFarming #familyfarm #organicfarm #farmlife

A short tour of the Tomato House at Neversink where we grow Intensive no till veg for profit. 

The Specs....
We seed into Winstrip 50 trays and germinate in a chamber
After a few weeks, we graft onto long season rootstock
Once Established and fill out their cell, they are potted onto 4” pots
Planted into the Hoop House 20” apart
Trellised with Hook and Wicket and hard pruned

Beds prepared with compost made on farm. 

Varieties - Cherries, Heirloom and Beefsteak

🍅🍅🍅NEWS- My Free Intro to Profitable Market Farming Course is available for the next few weeks. Bonus - A tour of the propagation House here at Neversink that is loaded with tips for efficient and successful plant starting. Signup through link in profile.

#neversinkfarm #hookandwicket #qlipr #marketfarmcourse #notill #smallfarm #hoophouse #intensivegrowing #notillfarming #conorcrickmore #smallfarm #marketfarm #marketfarming #neversinkfarmcourse #marketfarmcourse #familyfarm #farmlife #growingvegetables #growyourown #microfarm #humanscaleagricture #smallscalefarm

Early Cucumbers first trellis. 

Details
Started in Winstrip 50 trays and planted out after roots filled the cell. 
Plant inside hoop house with 12 or 15” spacing. 
Trellis with Qlipr hooks and wickets. 

This year we will be hard pruning the leaves for a couple of reasons. I want to better see the cucumbers to make harvesting easier. Lowering on wickets layers the plants so leaves can obscure the fruit. I also want to better see the hook and wicket system at work for cucumbers. 

News - Registration to My Free propagation workshop is open now. Get a tour of our prop house here at Neversink while I discuss efficiency in creating new plants. The prop house is the heart of every vegetable farm and it is where success begins. You will also gain access to the Introduction to Profitable Marketing Farming Workshop, made up of 30 lessons and hours of content. If you are thinking about creating a farm business, I am going to try and convince you to do it while giving you insight into what to expect. 

These workshops are only open for a limited time so check them out now. Link to register in profile.

#hookandwicket #trellisingcucumbers #neversinktools #neversinkfarmcourse #marketfarmcourse

This seasons compost windrow early in morning. I make hot compost every year at my farm. It is vital to intensive / high profit / small scale farming here at Neversink. 

Details
Mix of local manures from animals wintered in the barn
Layered with straw and rotted vegetable trimmings from the farm
Turned every three days for a month
Cured for three months

Today in the Spring veg hoop house. In this house we grow the most variety as it is our insurance crops. At one end is the washing station so to avoid pipes freezing we heat to just above freezing. All of our other grow houses are unheated. That means the crops grown in here are much safer, so every bed is something different to make sure our customers still get a great selection, no matter the weather. 
Can you name the crops?

Trellising of the indoor cucumbers today. At this stage, we add the second clip to the string. The string is attached to the qlipr hook. At this time we also add the wickets. The fun really starts once the cucumber gets up the hook.

There are only two clips which we will leap frog up to the metal hook. They will then be used to lower the cucumbers onto the wicket without ladders.

Today in the Flower Field. It is very early in the season, so the only flowers are either forced in the prop huse or growing in a hoop house. I thought I would show you the main flower growing field even though it is early. We grow mostly perrenials. It is about 2 to 1, perrenials to annuals. We do this for efficiency, increased production and because perrenials flowers have much more interest in the boquets for us. You can see the perrenial flowers growing fast and the peonies will be one of the first. One peony with anything esle makes a great bouquet. Flowers are a big part of what we grow here at Neversink Farm. This field is heavily composted just as the snow melts with well finished composted made here on the farm.

Planting onions today. Onions are one of the first crops to go out into the field in spring. 

Using a paperpot transplanter is very satisfying when doing this job. It is so fast already, there is no reason to rush it. 

Details - 
Onions planted to 4” paperpots using one pelleted seed per seed
Shallots planted to 4” paperpots 2 to 4 seeds per cell
Bed prepped with compost over winter kill cover crop, tilthed in.
Gridded to three rows on a bed.
Yellow onions, Red onions and shallots

Ranunculus growing inside the hoop house here at Neversink. A great flower that is ready up here in zone 5a, just in time for Mothers Day. It is also very easy to grow. 

Started from corms in Indestructible Bottom Trays in February. Planted out about three or four weeks later with a zipper into composted beds at three rows across.

Tomato house at Neversink Farm.  I was performing the first lowering today of the vines. A task I really like to do. 
Once vines get about 7 to 8’ we start lowering the vines. We do this every week for the rest of season. Vines grow 12 to 14” each week. Lowering keeps the work (pruning and harvesting) at a comfortable working height. It also is the best way to increase production in a small space. 
We use the Hook and Wicket system which keeps the vines off the ground along with the ability to lower without ladders. Check out more about it at the Neversink Tools YouTube channel.

In House 5 this morning. Growing great beets feels really really good. That is because it took a few years to do it consistently here at Neversink. We suffered from low boron and phosphorus for a while. Soil usually holds the answers on a farm.

The flower field at Neversink Farm. All of our cut flowers during the main season come from this 60’ x 100’ field. It produces more than we ever need even when we make 200 bouquets for market. It is all no till, and no plastic mulch or landscape fabric. 
We grow both perennials and annuals. Here is the fox glove, which perennial grown both for cutting and for transplanting into flower gardens around the farm.

Field in peak production at Neversink Farm. We have been pounded with rain then cooked in oppressive heat but we have managed to keep the veg in great condition. By we, I mean the soil did most of the work. Years of soil improvement and investment really pays off. 
Flowers were not so lucky as the blooms can’t survive super heavy rain but the plants were fine.

Fresh strawberries from the farm. We grow most of our fruit in a high tunnel.

Unbelievable !! I have never seen anything like it. These cucumbers were planted in early spring and are still producing and growing non stop using hook and wicket. That is only one planting for months. 
Neversink Farm is a testing and research ground for cutting edge Market Farming technology and systems. This is why we do it…to help make small farms even more resilient and efficient. @neversinkfarmtools 

With other trellising systems I was never able to go this long as they would become too unruly. I would normally have at least four rounds of cumber plantings during the season. This changes everything for us when it comes to our high production cukes. 

Check out the Neversink Tools YouTube for more info. 

#hookandwicket #gamechanger #randdfarming #smallfarmtools #toolresearch #makesmallfarmsbetter #cucumber #cucumbertrellsing

Cut flower field at Neversink Farm today. Technology being tested here is overhead watering of flowers. In the field outside, it is difficult and inefficient for us to use to drip for many reasons. Our goal with research is to figure out if overhead watering is the same as, worse than or better than rain. What time and day is best for watering? And is watering on a timer better than watering only after checking soil moisture. 
It has been nonstop rainy for weeks and previous to that it was completely dry. Great weather for research but not great for farming. 
Neversink Farm is focused on testing and developing technology for high production market farming. The results of which are used by @neversinkfarmtools for design, manufacturing, and transfer of information to farms. #wobblers #irrigation #cutflowers #farmtools #theaquifer #neversinktools

We are busy at Neversink with fall crops. Some are getting protected with LowCat tunnels (pictured), some are seeded now in the field (like carrots) and some are getting transplanted in a couple of weeks. 

I find Fall a harder shoulder season since timing is much more important. We are also getting winter crops ready and in the middle of summer harvest all at the same time. In NY, Fall and Winter growing is essential for high production, small space farming. 
We utilize LowCats and High Tunnels to achieve this.

The field from above during our morning walk. We check every day the state of the veg and field to determine what tasks need to be done. 

Besides growing and selling vegetables, we at Neversink Farm spend much of our time developing tools and systems for high production market farms around the world. So there is always the research to check on as well. We release new tools to market multiple times per year and at any one time we have more than a dozen systems and tools in development of which to keep track. 
@neversinkfarmtools 
Over the next couple of weeks, I will talk more about this. It is something I am extremely passionate about. 

#neversinktools #notill #farmtools #farmersusingtools #thelowcat #lowcat #notillfarming #madebyfarmers #designedbyfarmers

After people and soil, water is the farmers most important resource on the farm.  During morning field walks is a great time to water. You can allow the field and plants to dry before the afternoon sun.

I use wobblers in the field exclusively for irrigation. Great thing about wobbler sprinklers is that you don’t need many of them. Our field is broken into sections which are 8 rows, each 100’. Each section has four wobbler stands and we get perfect coverage for germination and watering in planted starts. There is a hydrant for every two sections.

Building a profitable small scale farming business begins with soil, water, infrastructure and systems. It is not about growing. Growing is what happens while you are running the business, creating infrastructure, and managing great systems. When the farmer is focused on those things, the growing improves on its own. 

It is very late in the season for us in NY and the field is producing well and remains without weeds. We have our problems but we have time to walk the field, start winter crops, put out LowCats, make plans, solve issues, and start preparing the field for winter. Without that time, it is impossible to maximize profits and grow a successful farm business. We grow the business every year yet get smaller in our production area. 

Nevesink Farm is about 1.2 acres in production, probably less.

Inside one of our hoop houses today. 🫑 Peppers being trellised on the left and hook and wicket 🥒 cucumbers on right. Peppers and cucumbers are trimmed to one stem. Peppers from @highmowingorganicseeds  Milena, Brocanto and Sprinter. 

Cucumbers were planted more than five months ago and are still producing. It is normal for us to have one planting of peppers but for cukes we usually have multiple successions, so this change has been an incredible boost for our production.

Spinach going into the hoop house today. Winter production has started. 
We use paperpots for this task and plant into our no till beds. 
We prep the beds with loads of compost which is made on farm and we also add a little organic fertilizer. We tilth it in and then plant after gridding straight lines to follow. 

We have been practicing no till for more than fifteen years and the soil gets more productive each year, even under constant production. It is an amazing thing to see. So many things that I thought I was solving with technique is actually being corrected with the soil. I am always learning.

The outside season is coming to an end for us. We can cover some of the crop to extend it, but most beds are going into cover crop.

We use a Jang three gang with the following mix

🌱 Oats - provide great structure to support the other crops. 
🌱 Field Peas - Nitrogen fixing from the air. 
🌱 Forage Radish - Great for no till as they provide aeration and help break up compaction. 

All of these cover crops die in winter and leave a protective mat of mulch. In spring we compost and tilth it in. Sometimes we plant straight into it.

The wash station is your farm business’s fulfillment center. It is where your production turns into product. It must be efficient and produce beautiful veg. Field from straight above.

Our field did not start off square when we first laid it out about a decade and a half ago. We leased this land initially and the piece we first rented was very oddly shaped. Since then, I have been moving it into square little by little every year. A square field with every bed the same length makes our planning much easier. We also have been able to put a cart along every 50' bed. This means that every bucket of compost or harvest tote is only carried on average 25'.

Cover crop coming in very well and without weed pressure which is always nice to see. We plant it as soon as the last crop is harvested and leave it to die in winter. Come spring, we cover with compost, then tilth and plant.

As a farmer, I talk a lot about, well, farming, but what is even more important to me is what we do when not farming. 

When we started our farm, we worked every day for two years to build the business. This is completely normal when creating any new business which takes investment, hard work, system and market development, and infrastructure. After that though, that work should hopefully translate into a well-run, efficient, and profitable enterprise that affords time with family and friends. 
We make projects to do as a family, cook meals together, just hang out, indulge in hobbies, and play on the farm. Then on Monday morning we get back to farming.

Storage Onions ready for the cold room. We grow yellow, red and two types of shallots for winter storage. 

We feel the bigger the onion the better. Just doubling the size of our onions meant hundreds of dollars in extra profit from each onion bed. That is thousands for the entire crop. Onions need well balanced soil, and good irrigation to get to maximum size. It took years to get it how we want it. 
We grew two shallot varieties this year to see which we preferred. We can’t decide.

In upstate NY it is getting cold and the season is winding down. Morning walks are chilly and frost is here. Garlic is getting planted, the last of the outdoor crops are being put into low tunnels, and the indoor crops are bursting to life.

I just got back from TN where we make our farm tools and I am so proud of what Neversink Tools has been able to accomplish this year. It is a great group of people who work very hard every day, to make that happen. Things have changed so much. We no longer just concern ourselves with our farm. Neversink Tools has grown and is able to now support farms working on social justice issues like food insecurity which was a goal we had when we started designing tools. The Neversink Farm Course just took on another large round of farmers that we get to help to be more profitable, and we are developing the next generation of farm tools. We can no longer go flat out for just our farm but that is ok. I enjoy the path we have taken and, in some ways, feel it is going to leave more of a positive impact on my kids and our community. Small farms are awesome. Being a farmer is a great life choice. The more small and successful farms in our world, the better.
@neversinkfarmtools @neversinkfarmcourse 
#NeversinkToolsGivesBack #FarmersHelpingFarmers #FarmTools #NeversinkTools #bekind #FamilyFarm #SmallFarmsareAwesome #FarmersHelpingFarmers #lowcat #lowcattunnel

Winter is just about here, so this will be the last outdoor field shot, I think. We have now moved indoors as the weather is too cold for us to work outside comfortably. 

I use a few tactics to keep my outdoor soil covered for the winter. 

Check my story for pictures of the following. 
Cover crop of peas, tillage radish and oats that winter kill. Old root crops get pulled and left on the beds. Harvested or bolted lettuce is left in the ground. Kale and chard are harvested until hard frost then is pulled and left in place. 

Come spring, we tilth in some compost and amendments and leave everything to rot for a few weeks.
